Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Fundamental Studies of the Roles and Interactions of Disparate Metals in p-d Alloy Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0747646
Meyer
Bimetallic catalysts have long been of scientific interest due to the intriguing possibilities that exist with regard to tuning the properties of the catalyst by varying the composition and creating unique local ensembles (active sites). Norskov and coworkers have greatly contributed to our understanding of catalysis through an analysis of the behavior of d-band transition metals. Norskov et al have shown that simple relationships hold equally for transition metals and their alloys and that the average d-band filling of the metal atoms in surface layer(s) acts a predictor of adsorption strength. However, there are a few catalyst systems of considerable importance (e. g. PtSn catalysts for catalytic reforming) where a d-band transition metal is alloyed with a non-transition metal (a metal with some occupancy in p-orbitals in the valence band) and the simple picture of examining the d-band center as a universal predictor seems insufficient. Therefore, this proposal through a combined theoretical/experimental approach will attempt to develop simple rules which could describe the adsorption behavior of p-d alloys (p-electron metals alloyed with d-band metals) in a similar way as has been previously established by Norskov et al for d-band transition metal alloys.

Intellectual Merit
The importance of this work is to extend established correlations which describe d-transition metal alloys to a new class of catalysts: alloys involving a d-band transition metal (e.g Pt) and one involving a main group metal (e.g. Sn or Zn). The work will be performed in a collaborative effort between experiment and theory utilizing multiple techniques. A variety of p-d alloy catalysts will be synthesized, and extensively characterized using EXAFS, in situ-XPS, and STEM-EELS. Following their characterization the catalyst will be tested under realistic operating conditions using a traditional microreactor in an effort to link the composition and structure of our materials to their reactivity (and selectivity) for two reactions of considerable importance: water gas shift and propane dehydrogenation. Density Functional Theory studies will examine the electronic structure of these materials and their stability under reaction conditions. Finally theory will be called upon to improve our understanding of the mechanism and thereby aid our design of new catalysts.

Broader Impact
This study is of a very general nature and as such may ultimately lead toward ?rules of thumb? in catalyst design as Norskov?s seminal work regarding d-band theory which this work hopes to augment and emulate. Multiple collaborative investigators will work together with the students on this project, each with a unique research perspective (partially as a product of the institutions with which they are affiliated). Therefore the student will gain an appreciation of research at industrial (Dr. Jeff Miller of BP), governmental (Dr. Jeremy Kropf of Argonne National Laboratory) and academic institutions (Professor Robert Klie and John Regalbuto of the University of Illinois at Chicago; Prof. Fabio Ribeiro of Purdue University). The PI intends to make considerable use general user facilities at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Lab (for EXAFS) and the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Lawrence Berkeley Labs (for high pressure XPS) which will expose the students to a large variety of research environments as well as a number of synergistic techniques. This work involves practical examples which illustrate the usefulness of undergraduate level chemical thermodynamics and reaction kinetics which can be incorporated into existing courses taught by the PI. The test reactions of interest for these catalysts involve both traditional hydrocarbon catalysis and hydrogen production, a reaction of increasing potential importance to our energy future. These examples will be integrated in the appropriate context to the department?s new introductory course for first year students in chemical engineering. Finally, it is hoped to extend this even further to high school level through interaction with the Illinois Math and Science Academy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary focus of this work was determine how alloying perturbs reactivity of supported metal nanoparticle heterogeneous catalysts. Heterogeneous catalysts based on supported metal nanoparticles are used in about 85% of industrial scale processes for fuels and chemicals. Monometallic systems are often constrained by a single interaction between an adsorbate molecule and the catalyst surface. Therefore, bimetallic (and even multi-metallic) alloys allow for potential tuning of the adsorbate-catalyst interaction. However, even after many years of study, the relationship between electronic modification (changing how strong an adsorbate binds) and geometric modification (changing the configuration of how the adsorbate binds) through alloying is not completely understood.
In the course of this grant, we have studied 3 different systems and examined how alloying may change the reactivity. First, palladium zinc (PdZn) and nickel zinc (NiZn) were examined as potential replacements to Copper as low temperature water gas shift catalysts. Water gas shift is a highly important reaction for tuning the ratio of hydrogen to carbon monoxide in syngas, an important feed for synthesizing methanol and other valuable products. Copper catalysts are known to sinter over time. In this work, NiZn was proposed as a potential alternative to copper as its electronic structure closely mimics that of copper and therefore it should supply similar activity. Density Functional Theory calculations confirmed that the primary mechanism for water gas shift on NiZn and PdZn does indeed follow that of copper. It is not clear experimentally if NiZn will be robust enough under reaction conditions to give improved performance.
A second project examined the role of alloying in tuning the selectivity of alkane isomerization and dehydrogenation. Propane dehydrogenation to make valuable propene is a process of emerging importance as propane is highly plentiful in shale gas and demand for propene as a platform for chemicals and polymers surges. Our work showed that the presence of Zn when alloyed with Pd, dramatically altered the selectivity, nearly eliminating the unwanted hydrogenolysis and maintained superior resistance to deactivation by coking. Adsorption studies of CO, indicate that the PdZn alloy lacks the sites that allow molecules to bind to more than one Pd atom. Single Pd atoms are sufficient to allow dehydrogenation to occur without C-C bond cleavage.
Finally we have examined the selective hydrogenation of acrolein to allyl alcohol as a third probe reaction. Acrolein hydrogenation is a challenging case because while acrolein is the simplest β unsaturated aldehyde, it is also the most difficult to selectively hydrogenate due to the lack of steric protection of the double bond. Selective hydrogenation to the unsaturated alcohol is thermodynamically unfavorable by 35 kJ/mol and therefore the catalyst must kinetically control the relative rates of C=C hydrogenation vs. C=O hydrogenation. Our primary objective is to understand how alloying of Ag may influence the activity and selectivity. Our work has been focused on a particular class of alloys: single atom alloys whereby a more active metal is dispersed in a less active metal at high dilution which results in the creation of unique active sites of isolated atoms of the active metal. For example, we have examined alloys of Ag and Pd where the Ag:Pd is greater than 100:1. In these cases, it is conceived that the Pd atoms are completely isolated (i.e. surrounded by Ag). Alloys containing Pd showed superior activity and even superior selectivity to monometallic Ag for the same particle size.  We have examined how the synthesis method relates to the catalytic performance in these systems as agglomeration of Pd during the synthesis process can result in highly active but poorly selective catalysts.
Through these examples, we have shown that geometric effects of tuning the adsorbate configuration can be used as an additional lever beyond electronic structure effects in steering catalyst activity and selectivity. In addition, some of the critical calculations described in this work were performed by undergraduate researchers through REU supplements and by students from the Illinois Math and Science Academy in Aurora through their Student Inquiry and Research program.
